member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientTimeouts.BrowseAccessPaths
member.summary: Browse access paths timeout. Number of milliseconds. For BrowseAccessPaths method of the EasyDAClient, this value determines the maximum amount of time this method waits for the signal that the operation was completed (either with success or failure).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientTimeouts.BrowseNodes
member.summary: Browse nodes timeout. Number of milliseconds. For BrowseBranches, BrowseLeaves and BrowseNodes methods of the EasyDAClient object, this value determines the maximum amount of time these methods wait for the signal from the OPC server that the operation was completed (either with success or failure).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientTimeouts.BrowseProperties
member.summary: Browse properties timeout. Number of milliseconds. For BrowseProperties method of the EasyDAClient, this value determines the maximum amount of time this method waits for the signal that the operation was completed (either with success or failure).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientTimeouts.BrowseServers
member.summary: Browse servers timeout. Number of milliseconds. For BrowseServers method of the EasyDAClient, this value determines the maximum amount of time this method waits for the signal that the operation was completed (either with success or failure).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientTimeouts.GetProperty
member.summary: Get property timeout. Number of milliseconds. For GetPropertyValue and GetMultiplePropertyValues methods of the EasyDAClient object, this value determines the maximum amount of time these methods wait for the signal from the OPC server that the operation was completed (either with success or failure).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientTimeouts.ReadItem
member.summary: Read item timeout. Number of milliseconds. For ReadItem, ReadItemValue, ReadMultipleItems and ReadMultipleItemValues methods of the EasyDAClient object, this value determines the maximum amount of time these methods wait for the signal that the read operation was completed (either with success or failure). For ReadItemValue and ReadMultipleItemValues methods, the received data must also be marked with Good OPC quality.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientTimeouts.WriteItem
member.summary: Write item timeout. Number of milliseconds. For WriteItem, WriteItemValue, WriteMultipleItems and WriteMultipleItemValues methods of the EasyDAClient object, this value determines the maximum amount of time these methods wait for the signal from the OPC server that the write operation was completed (either with success or failure).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.TopicProcessingIntervalTimeout
member.summary: Topic processing interval timeout. Number of milliseconds. When the incoming requests related to OPC items pause for this interval, the requests collected so far are applied to the OPC server.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero, or it must be equal to .

Normally, incoming requests are logically grouped by the component, and processed according to how the application has structured them. This interval will therefore only have some effect under heavy system load.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.TopicProcessingTotalTimeout
member.summary: Topic processing total timeout. Number of milliseconds. When the incoming requests related to OPC items are being collected for this period, the requests collected so far are applied to the OPC server.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero.

Normally, incoming requests are logically grouped by the component, and processed according to how the application has structured them. This interval will therefore only have some effect under heavy system load.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.PercentDeadbandBucketsPerDecade
member.summary: Number of buckets per decade of percent deadband.
member.value: The percent deadband values (from 0.0 to 100.0) are divided into "buckets", using a logarithmic scale. This number specifies how many buckets will exist between values 10.0 - 100.0, and also 1.0 - 10.0, 0.1 - 1.0, and so forth. Percent deadbands requested will be adjusted so that the nearest bucket that fully satisfies the percent deadband requirement is used (i.e. the system may choose a percent deadband lower than requested, but not higher).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.UpdateRateBucketsPerDecade
member.summary: Number of buckets per decade of update rate.
member.value: The update rate values are divided into "buckets", using a logarithmic scale. This number specifies how many buckets will exist between values 100.0 - 1000.0, 10.0 - 100.0, 1.0 - 10.0, 0.1 - 1.0, and so forth, in both directions. Update rates requested will be adjusted so that the nearest bucket that fully satisfies the update rate requirement is used (i.e. the system may choose an update rate that is faster than requested, but not slower).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.ElementNameCaseSensitive
member.summary: Indicates whether the element names in the OPC server are case sensitive. This value is used when the element name is matched with element name filter pattern for OPC-DA 1.0 and 2.0 servers that generally cannot do the element name filtering internally.
member.remarks: This parameter applies only during browsing, and only in somewhat special case. For browsing, there is a parameter where you can specify a name filter (a string like "AB*", for examples), and the browse operation would return only the items that match the filter. In newest OPC DA specification (3.0), this filter is passed to the OPC server and interpreted there, giving us no choice to influence how it is interpreted. If your target server happens to be OPC DA 1.0 or 2.0, then there is (generally) no name filtering guaranteed to be implemented on the server side. We therefore get all the items from the server, ad then post-filter them on the client side. In that case, you can influence the case-sensitivity of that filtering using this parameter. Note that other aspects of browsing (such as case-sensitivity of the parent node ID passed to the browse operation) are not influenced by this parameter.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.RequestQueueSize
member.summary: Size of the internal queue that holds requests related to operations on OPC items.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.LinkCallbackQueueSize
member.summary: Size of the internal queue that holds callback data from the OPC server.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.ResponseQueueSize
member.summary: Size of the internal queue that holds responses related to operations on OPC items.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.BrowseNodesChunk
member.summary: Number of nodes requested in one call when browsing for OPC branches or leaves.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDAClientParameters.TopicRetrialPeriod
member.summary: Topic retrial period. Number of milliseconds. Determines how often will the component run the internal process to re-connect to OPC items that have failed (e.g. due to incorrect Item IDs).

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.TopicRetrialDelay
member.summary: Topic retrial delay. Number of milliseconds. If a specific OPC item is found to be not operational, further attempts to use it will not be made until the topic retrial delay elapses. One of typical reasons for entering the topic retrial period is using an unknown OPC ItemID, which can later become correct when the OPC server configuration is updated.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.UpdateRateNegativeHysteresis
member.summary: Hysteresis for negative update rate changes. In percent, between 0.0 and 100.0. Requests to make the update rate of OPC item faster (i.e. lower value) will be ignored if the percentual change in update rate value is lower than the value of this property.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.UpdateRatePositiveHysteresis
member.summary: Hysteresis for positive update rate changes. In percent, between 0.0 and 100.0. Requests to make the update rate of OPC item slower (i.e. higher value) will be ignored if the percentual change in update rate value is lower than the value of this property.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.AbandonIntervalMinimum
member.summary: Abandon interval minimum. Number of milliseconds. The OPC item is considered "abandoned" if no requests to it has been made for abandon interval. In such case its update rate is automatically adjusted to a slower value. The abandon interval is computed using the latest update rate and , but it is never shorter than value of this property.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.AbandonRateMultiplier
member.summary: Abandon rate multiplier. Must be greater than or equal to 1.0. The OPC item is considered "abandoned" if no requests to it have been made for abandon interval. In such case its update rate is automatically adjusted to a slower value. The abandon interval is computed by multiplying the latest update rate and the value of this property, but it is never shorter than .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.SpeedupWeight
member.summary: Speed-up weight. Must be greater than or equal to 0.0. When the newly observed request rate for an OPC item is detected to be faster than the current update rate, the new update rate is computed. The value of this property is a relative weight of newly observed request rate to the update rate currently in use.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.SlowdownWeight
member.summary: Slow-down weight. Must be greater than or equal to 0.0. When the newly observed request rate for an OPC item is detected to be slower than the current update rate, the new update rate is computed. The value of this property is a relative weight of newly observed request rate to the update rate currently in use.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.FastestAutomaticUpdateRate
member.summary: Fastest automatic update rate. Number of milliseconds. When the system automatically modifies the update rate of an OPC item, it never chooses a rate that is faster (has lower value) than the value of this property.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.SlowestAutomaticUpdateRate
member.summary: Slowest automatic update rate. Number of milliseconds. When the system automatically modifies the update rate of an OPC item, it never chooses a rate that is slower (has higher value) than the value of this property.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.FastestManualUpdateRate
member.summary: Fastest manual update rate. Number of milliseconds. If your application specifies an update rate that is faster (has lower value) than the value of this property, the value of this property will be used instead.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.SlowestManualUpdateRate
member.summary: Slowest manual update rate. Number of milliseconds. If your application specifies an update rate that is slower (has higher value) than the value of this property, the value of this property will be used instead.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.LowestManualPercentDeadband
member.summary: If your application specifies a percent deadband that is lower than the value of this property, the value of this property will be used instead.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero, and less than or equal to 100.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.HighestManualPercentDeadband
member.summary: If your application specifies a percent deadband that is higher than the value of this property, the value of this property will be used instead.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero, and less than or equal to 100.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Engine.EasyDATopicParameters.ExactManualGroupMatch
member.summary: When this setting is on, explicit item subscriptions honor the requested update rate precisely (without attempting to merge the neighboring rates into "buckets").

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.DAMappingProvider.SharedInstance
member.summary: A default, shared instance of the mapping provider object.

remarks.para: Use this property with care, as its usability is limited. Its main use is for testing, and for non-library application code where just a single instance is sufficient.
The default instance is not suitable for Windows Forms or similar environments, where a specific may be used with each form.

We also do not recommend using the default instance for library code, due to conflicts that may arise if your library sets some instance parameters which may not be the same as what other libraries or the final application expects.

member.summary: Obtains a type mapping definition for a given type, either by looking up an already loaded definition, or loading it, if not known to the provider yet.
member.param: The type for which the type mapping definition should be obtained.
member.returns: The existing or newly loaded type mapping definition; null if the type is not for mapping.

remarks.para:
supports following meta-members:
GroupParameters: , an object containing subscription parameters, such as the requested update rate.
NodeDescriptor: , the descriptor of the OPC node involved in the operation.
ReadParameters: , the read parameters (such as data source or value age).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.DAItemIdTemplateAttribute.ItemIdTemplateString
member.summary: The template string for item Id.

remarks.para: Null is allowed, because it allows to disable the template use from certain level onwards.

Following macros can be used in template strings:
$(ParentNodePath) The OPC node path of the parent node. Only used with OPC XML.
$(ParentItemId) The OPC Item Id of parent node.
$(BrowseName) The browse name of current node.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.DAItemIdTemplateAttribute.NodePathTemplateString

$(BrowseName) The browse name of current node.

member.summary: Determines whether the node will be mapped in a deferred manner.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.DAReadAttribute.ValueAge
member.summary: Determines the age of value you would like to obtain (in milliseconds).

remarks.para: This value is significant only when the property is set to ByValueAge.
The value must be greater than or equal to zero, or it must be equal to .
When the value is , the value will always be provided from the memory, i.e. without actually accessing the OPC server.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.DAClientMapper.DefaultClient
member.summary: A default client object.

remarks.para: The default client object is used when no client object is specified in the constructor of the mapper.
The initial value is equal to ; all its limitations apply.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.DAClientMapper.SharedInstance
member.summary: A default, shared instance of the mapper object.

remarks.para: Use this property with care, as its usability is limited. Its main use is for testing, and for non-library application code where just a single instance is sufficient.
The default instance is not suitable for Windows Forms or similar environments, where a specific may be used with each form.

We also do not recommend using the default instance for library code, due to conflicts that may arise if your library sets some instance parameters which may not be the same as what other libraries or the final application expects.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.Resource1.DAClientMapper_ItemMissingGroupParameters
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The data access item mapping cannot participate in Subscribe operation, because it contains no group parameters. If you are using attribute-based mapping, you might be missing DASubscriptionAttribute. If you do not want the mapping participate in Subscribe operation, you can exclude it using the Operations member of the mapping (or Operations argument of DAItemAttribute). This error should not happen unless you explicitly specify the values in mapping context, because the default mapping context contains de [rest of string was truncated]";.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.Resource1.DAClientMapper_ItemMissingNodeDescriptor
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The member cannot be mapped as OPC data access item, because no node descriptor has been specified in the mapping context. You might be missing the DANodeAttribute..

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.Resource1.DAClientMapper_ItemMissingReadParameters
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The data access item mapping cannot participate in Read operation, because it contains no read parameters. If you are using attribute-based mapping, you might be missing DAReadAttribute. If you do not want the mapping participate in Read operation, you can exclude it using the Operations member of the mapping (or Operations argument of DAItemAttribute). This error should not happen unless you explicitly specify the values in mapping context, because the default mapping context contains default read paramete [rest of string was truncated]";.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.Resource1.DAClientMapper_ItemMissingServerDescriptor
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The member cannot be mapped as OPC data access item, because no server descriptor has been specified in the mapping context. You might be missing the ServerAttribute, or forgot to specify the server descriptor in the mapping context template in the mapper..

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.LiveMapping.Resource1.DAClientMapper_PropertyMissingNodeDescriptor
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The member cannot be mapped as OPC data access property, because no node descriptor has been specified in the mapping context. member.remarks: The notifications will contain for each OPC item change. All OPC items in one must be assignable to the type. Typically, you will create the observable for items of the same type. You can also choose a common denominator type; for example, if you use for , you can use it in a type-less manner).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.EasyDAClient.SharedInstance
member.summary: A default, shared instance of the client object.

remarks.para: Use this property with care, as its usability is limited. Its main use is for testing, and for non-library application code where just a single instance is sufficient.
The default instance is not suitable for Windows Forms or similar environments, where a specific may be used with each form.

We also do not recommend using the default instance for library code, due to conflicts that may arise if your library sets some instance parameters which may not be the same as what other libraries or the final application expects.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DALimitChoice
member.summary: The Limit bit field of OPC quality.

remarks.para: The Limit Field is valid regardless of the QualityChoice and Substatus. In some cases such as Sensor Failure it can provide useful diagnostic information.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DALimitChoice.LimitLow

member.summary: High Limited. The value has pegged at some high limit.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DALimitChoice.LimitConst
member.summary: Constant. The value is a constant and cannot move.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities
member.summary: Contains pre-defined constants of internal values.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.BadNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. The value is bad but no specific reason is known.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.UncertainNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. There is no specific reason why the value is uncertain.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.GoodNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. The value is good. There are no special conditions.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.ConfigError
member.summary: Configuration Error. There is some server specific problem with the configuration. For example the item in question has been deleted from the configuration.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.NotConnected
member.summary: Not Connected. The input is required to be logically connected to something but is not. This quality may reflect that no value is available at this time, for reasons like the value may have not been provided by the data source.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.DeviceFailure
member.summary: Device Failure. A device failure has been detected.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.SensorFailure
member.summary: Sensor Failure. A sensor failure had been detected (the Limits field can provide additional diagnostic information in some situations).

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.LastKnown
member.summary: Last Known Value. Communications have failed. However, the last known value is available. Remark: The age of the value may be determined from the TIMESTAMP in the OPCITEMSTATE.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.CommFailure
member.summary: Comm Failure. Communications have failed. There is no last known value is available.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.OutOfService
member.summary: Out of Service. The block is off scan or otherwise locked. This quality is also used when the active state of the item or the group containing the item is InActive.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.WaitingForInitialData
member.summary: Waiting for Initial Data. After Items are added to a group, it may take some time for the server to actually obtain values for these items. In such cases the client might perform a read (from cache), or establish a ConnectionPoint based subscription and/or execute a Refresh on such a subscription before the values are available. This substatus is only available from OPC DA 3.0 or newer servers.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.LastUsable
member.summary: Last Usable Value. Whatever was writing this value has stopped doing so. The returned value should be regarded as stale. Remark: This differs from a BAD value with Substatus 5 (Last Known Value). That status is associated specifically with a detectable communications error on a fetched value. This error is associated with the failure of some external source to put something into the value within an acceptable period of time. Remark: The age of the value can be determined from the TIMESTAMP in OPCITEMSTATE.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.SensorCal
member.summary: Sensor Not Accurate. Either the value has pegged at one of the sensor limits (in which case the limit field should be set to 1 or 2) or the sensor is otherwise known to be out of calibration via some form of internal diagnostics (in which case the limit field should be 0).

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.EguExceeded
member.summary: Engineering Units Exceeded. The returned value is outside the limits defined for this parameter. Remark: In this case (per the Fieldbus Specification) the Limits field indicates which limit has been exceeded but does NOT necessarily imply that the value cannot move farther out of range.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.Subnormal
member.summary: Sub-Normal. The value is derived from multiple sources and has less than the required number of Good sources.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.LocalOverride
member.summary: Local Override. The value has been Overridden. Typically this is means the input has been disconnected and a manually entered value has been forced.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQuality
member.summary: Represents the quality state for an item's data value.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQuality.DefaultInternalValue
member.summary: Default (enumerated) internal value. Equals to zero.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQuality.DefaultNumericalValue
member.summary: Default numerical internal value. Equals to zero.

member.summary: Gets the QualityChoice bit field.

remarks.para: You cannot set the QualityChoice using a property; use SetQualityAndSubstatus method instead. This approach is needed as the semantics of the Status depends on the QualityChoice, and therefore setting just QualityChoice could lead to inconsistent or undesired contents of the DAQuality.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualityChoice
member.summary: The QualityChoice bit field, i.e. the most significant part of the OPC quality flags.

remarks.para: The OPC specification uses the name "Quality" for this bit field, which makes it possible to confuse with the full OPC quality value. We have made up the name "QualityChoice" in order to reduce the chances for confusion.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualityChoice.Bad
member.summary: Bad. Value is not useful for reasons indicated by the Substatus.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualityChoice.Uncertain
member.summary: Uncertain. The quality of the value is uncertain for reasons indicated by the Substatus.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualityChoice.Good
member.summary: Good. The Quality of the value is Good.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice
member.summary: Status is a combination of QualityChoice and Substatus. Which Substatus values can be used depend on QualityChoice.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.BadNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. Substatus for BAD Quality: The value is bad but no specific reason is known.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.UncertainNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: There is no specific reason why the value is uncertain.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.GoodNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. Substatus for GOOD Quality: The value is good. There are no special conditions.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.ConfigError
member.summary: Configuration Error. Substatus for BAD Quality: There is some server specific problem with the configuration. For example the item in question has been deleted from the configuration.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.NotConnected
member.summary: Not Connected. Substatus for BAD Quality: The input is required to be logically connected to something but is not. This quality may reflect that no value is available at this time, for reasons like the value may have not been provided by the data source.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.DeviceFailure
member.summary: Device Failure. Substatus for BAD Quality: A device failure has been detected.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.SensorFailure
member.summary: Sensor Failure. Substatus for BAD Quality: A sensor failure had been detected (the Limits field can provide additional diagnostic information in some situations).

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.LastKnown
member.summary: Last Known Value. Substatus for BAD Quality: Communications have failed. However, the last known value is available. Remark: The age of the value may be determined from the TIMESTAMP in the OPCITEMSTATE.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.CommFailure
member.summary: Comm Failure. Substatus for BAD Quality: Communications have failed. There is no last known value is available.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.OutOfService
member.summary: Out of Service. Substatus for BAD Quality: The block is off scan or otherwise locked. This quality is also used when the active state of the item or the group containing the item is InActive.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.WaitingForInitialData
member.summary: Waiting for Initial Data. Substatus for BAD Quality: After Items are added to a group, it may take some time for the server to actually obtain values for these items. In such cases the client might perform a read (from cache), or establish a ConnectionPoint based subscription and/or execute a Refresh on such a subscription before the values are available. This substatus is only available from OPC DA 3.0 or newer servers.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.LastUsable
member.summary: Last Usable Value. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: Whatever was writing this value has stopped doing so. The returned value should be regarded as stale. Remark: This differs from a BAD value with Substatus 5 (Last Known Value). That status is associated specifically with a detectable communications error on a fetched value. This error is associated with the failure of some external source to put something into the value within an acceptable period of time. Remark: The age of the value can be determined from the TIMESTAMP in OPCITEMSTATE.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.SensorCal
member.summary: Sensor Not Accurate. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: Either the value has pegged at one of the sensor limits (in which case the limit field should be set to 1 or 2) or the sensor is otherwise known to be out of calibration via some form of internal diagnostics (in which case the limit field should be 0).

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.EguExceeded
member.summary: Engineering Units Exceeded. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: The returned value is outside the limits defined for this parameter. Remark: In this case (per the Fieldbus Specification) the Limits field indicates which limit has been exceeded but does NOT necessarily imply that the value cannot move farther out of range.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.Subnormal
member.summary: Sub-Normal. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: The value is derived from multiple sources and has less than the required number of Good sources.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.LocalOverride
member.summary: Local Override. Substatus for GOOD Quality: The value has been Overridden. Typically this is means the input has been disconnected and a manually entered value has been forced.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension
member.summary: Contains extension methods to the interface.

remarks.para: NOTE: This class is intentionally *not* placed in the Extensions namespace, but rather alongside the extendee. The extension methods in this class are commonly used, and from the point of view of the developer, can be considered as part of the interface. In addition, this placement allows less namespaces references in typical projects, and better consistency with the COM interfaces (as only methods from this extension class may appear in the COM interfaces).
Other extension classes may exist as well.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension.ReadItem(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.OperationModel.DAReadItemArguments)

overloads.summary: Reads a named item from an OPC server. Value, quality and timestamp are returned.

remarks.para: The server can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.
The ReadItem method only waits for the first update from the server (or until the timeout elapses); it does not wait until the quality becomes "uncertain" or "good".

member.summary: Reads a named item using an object that holds all necessary arguments.
member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.
Arguments specifying what to read from an OPC-DA server.
member.returns: If successful, the function returns a object. The object contains the value, timestamp and quality of the OPC item requested.
member.exception: Thrown when the OPC operation fails.

member.summary: Reads a named item using individual parameters specifying its location, and a specific data type.
member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.

Name of the machine. Determines the computer on which the OPC server is located. May be an empty string, in which case the OPC server is assumed to exist on the local computer or at the computer specified for it by DCOM configuration.
Contains ProgID of the OPC server to read from.
Contains OPC item identifier.
Specifies the data type requested. Passing will cause the value be returned in server's canonical data type.
member.returns: If successful, the function returns a object. The object contains the value, timestamp and quality of the OPC item requested.
member.exception: Thrown when the OPC operation fails.

member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.

Name of the machine. Determines the computer on which the OPC server is located. May be an empty string, in which case the OPC server is assumed to exist on the local computer or at the computer specified for it by DCOM configuration.
Contains ProgID of the OPC server to read from.
Contains OPC item identifier.
Specifies the data type requested. Passing will cause the value be returned in server's canonical data type.
The age of value you would like to obtain (in milliseconds).
member.returns: If successful, the function returns a object. The object contains the value, timestamp and quality of the OPC item requested.

remarks.para: The data source (a device, OPC server's cache, or a value from OPC client component memory cache) is dynamically determined based on the valueAge argument.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension.ReadItemValue(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerDescriptor,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAItemDescriptor)

overloads.summary: Reads a named item from an OPC server. Only the item value is returned (quality and timestamp are not returned).

remarks.para: The server can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

Use this method if you are only interested in the actual value of the OPC item. Use ReadItem method if you also need the quality or timestamp. The ReadItemValue method makes it very easy to obtain the actual data value with just one function call.
The ReadItemValue method waits until the quality becomes "good", or the timeout elapses.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension.ReadMultipleItems(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerDescriptor,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAItemDescriptor[])
member.overloads: Reads named items from an OPC server or OPC servers. Values, qualities and timestamps are returned.

remarks.para: The servers can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

The ReadMultipleItems method only waits for the first update from the server (or until the timeout elapses) for each item; it does not wait until the quality becomes "uncertain" or "good". The function performs all individual operations in parallel, but only returns after all individual operations are completed (or their timeouts elapse).
This method does not throw an exception in case of OPC operation failures. Instead, the eventual exception related to each item is returned in Exception property of each returned element.

member.summary: Reads multiple named items from a single OPC server, using descriptor objects for the OPC server and OPC-DA items.
member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.
The OPC server involved in the operation.
Array of OPC items involved in the operation.
member.returns: The function returns an array of objects. The indices of elements in the output array are the same as those in the input array, .
member.remarks: The size of the input array will become the size of the output array. The element positions (indices) in the output array are the same as in the input array.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension.ReadMultipleItems(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerDescriptor,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAItemDescriptor[],OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAReadParameters)

member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.
The OPC server involved in the operation.
Array of OPC items involved in the operation.
Contains parameters for OPC read operations, such as the data source or value age.
member.returns: The function returns an array of objects. The indices of elements in the output array are the same as those in the input array, .

overloads.summary: Reads named items from an OPC server or OPC servers. Only the item values are returned (qualities and timestamps are not returned).

remarks.para: The servers can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

The ReadMultipleItemValues method waits until the quality becomes "good", or the timeout elapses, for each item. The function performs all individual operations in parallel, but only returns after all individual operations are completed (or their timeouts elapse).
This method does not throw an exception in case of OPC operation failures. Instead, the eventual exception related to each item is returned in Exception property of each returned element.

member.summary: Reads multiple named item values from a single OPC server, using descriptor objects for the OPC server and OPC-DA items.
member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.
The OPC server involved in the operation.
Array of OPC items involved in the operation.
member.returns: The function returns an array of objects. The indices of elements in the output array are the same as those in the input array, .
member.remarks: The size of the input array will become the size of the output array. The element positions (indices) in the output array are the same as in the input array.

member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.
member.returns: The method returns a keyed collection of values, each containing information about a particular OPC server found on the specified machine. The keys of the keyed collection are the server's CLSIDs.
member.exception: Thrown when the OPC operation fails.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient.ReadMultipleItems(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.OperationModel.DAReadItemArguments[])
member.overloads: Reads named items from an OPC server or OPC servers. Values, qualities and timestamps are returned.

remarks.para: The servers can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

The ReadMultipleItems method only waits for the first update from the server (or until the timeout elapses) for each item; it does not wait until the quality becomes "uncertain" or "good". The function performs all individual operations in parallel, but only returns after all individual operations are completed (or their timeouts elapse).
This method does not throw an exception in case of OPC operation failures. Instead, the eventual exception related to each item is returned in Exception property of each returned element.

member.summary: Reads multiple named items, using array of argument objects as an input.
member.param: Array of arguments, one element per each OPC item involved in the operation.
member.returns: The function returns an array of objects. The indices of elements in the output array are the same as those in the input array, .
member.remarks: The size of the input array will become the size of the output array. The element positions (indices) in the output array are the same as in the input array.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient.ReadMultipleItemValues(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.OperationModel.DAReadItemArguments[])

overloads.summary: Reads named items from an OPC server or OPC servers. Only the item values are returned (qualities and timestamps are not returned).

remarks.para: The servers can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

The ReadMultipleItemValues method waits until the quality becomes "good", or the timeout elapses, for each item. The function performs all individual operations in parallel, but only returns after all individual operations are completed (or their timeouts elapse).
This method does not throw an exception in case of OPC operation failures. Instead, the eventual exception related to each item is returned in Exception property of each returned element.

member.summary: Reads multiple named item values from a single OPC server, using array of argument objects as an input.
member.param: Array of arguments, one element per each OPC item involved in the operation.
member.returns: The function returns an array of objects. The indices of elements in the output array are the same as those in the input array, .
member.remarks: The size of the input array will become the size of the output array. The element positions (indices) in the output array are the same as in the input array.

The servers can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.
This method does not throw an exception in case of OPC operation failures. Instead, the eventual exception related to each item is returned in Exception property of each returned element.

The server can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ClientReconnectDelay
member.summary: Client reconnect delay. Number of milliseconds. If operations on specific OPC server are found to be failing, the server is disconnected, and further connection is retried only after the client reconnect delay elapses.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ExecutionContext
member.summary: Indicates execution contexts in which the OPC server object is to be run.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ServerFailedReconnectDelay
member.summary: Server failed reconnect delay. Number of milliseconds. If the OPC server indicates that vendor specific fatal error has occurred within the server, the server is disconnected, and further connection is retried only after this delay elapses.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ServerShutdownReconnectDelay
member.summary: Server shutdown reconnect delay. Number of milliseconds. If the OPC server indicates that it needs to shutdown, the server is disconnected, and further connection is retried only after this delay elapses.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ServerStatusCheckPeriod
member.summary: Server status check period. Number of milliseconds. Determines how often the system periodically checks the status of the OPC server (by calling IOPCServer::GetStatus method).

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .
This parameters has effect in both OPC Classic and OPC XML-DA.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.TurnOffActivationSecurity
member.summary: Indicates that activation security should be turned off when the OPC server object is created.
member.remarks: For more information, see Turning Off Activation Security in MSDN.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.TurnOffCallSecurity
member.summary: Sets the authentication level for COM object access to None.
member.remarks: This settings has effect only when is true.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.UseCustomSecurity
member.summary: Indicates that custom security settings should be used for COM object access.
member.remarks: When true, the COM security settings of the application are controlled by the application itself, and are not influenced by the settings specified in DCOM Configuration. Unless specified otherwise, access is allowed to everyone, authentication level is set to Connect and the impersonation level is set to Impersonate.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyEngineParameters.AutoAdjustmentPeriod
member.summary: Auto adjustment period. Number of milliseconds. Specifies how often the engine automatically adjusts the parameters (such as update rate) of OPC items to match the observed usage pattern (e.g. the frequency of reading the item).

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyEngineParameters.GarbageCollectionPeriod
member.summary: Garbage collection period. Number of milliseconds. Specifies how often the engine reviews the connected OPC servers and items and disconnects from those that are no longer needed.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyEngineParameters.WorkerSleepDelay
member.summary: Worker sleep delay. Number of milliseconds. Specifies how often the engine checks the need to perform tasks such garbage collection, rate adjustment, and final cleanup.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyEngineParameters.DefaultEventQueueSize
member.summary: Default event queue size. The maximum size of the queue each client object uses to temporarily hold generated events before they are consumed by the application. Events that do not fit into the queue will be lost. You should set the size to a number that is sufficient to cope with the difference between the rate events are generated and the rate your application is able to consume them.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.LiveMapping.ServerAttribute.MachineName
member.summary: Name of the machine. Determines the computer on which the OPC server is located. May be an empty string, in which case the OPC server is assumed to exist on the local computer or at the computer specified for it by DCOM configuration.
member.remarks: Machine resources are named using the naming scheme of the network transport. By default, all UNC ("\\server" or "server") and DNS names ("domain.com", "example.microsoft.com", or "135.5.33.19") names are allowed.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.OperationModel.OpcException
member.summary: Exceptions arising from OPC operations.
member.remarks: In general, you cannot safely prevent these exceptions from happening. Various conditions external to your code can cause OPC failures, e.g. network problems, improper OPC server configuration, etc. For this reason, you should always expect that an OPC operation can fail.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.OperationModel.OpcException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with a specified error message, and a reference to the inner exception that is the cause this exception.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.NodeDescriptor.MakeArgumentString(System.Boolean)

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.NodeDescriptor.Match(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.NodeDescriptor)
member.summary: Determines whether the node descriptor matches another node descriptor.
member.param: The node descriptor to match against.
member.returns: Returns true if two node descriptors match; otherwise, returns false.
member.remarks: Two node descriptors match if any information that is present in both node descriptors is equal. For example, if a node Id in one of the node descriptors is not present (null), a node Id in the other node descriptor can be anything, or also not present. But if a node Id is present in both node descriptors, it must be the same node Id. Same rules apply to the browse path portion of the node descriptor.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Clsid
member.summary: Gets or sets OPC server's class identifier (CLSID).

remarks.para: A CLSID is a globally unique identifier that identifies an OPC server. The OPC server needs to register its CLSID with the system.
In VBScript, use instead.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.ClsidString
member.summary: Contains the CLSID string of the server.

remarks.para: The value is an empty string if no CLSID for the server is given.

member.summary: Gets or sets a user readable name for the OPC server.
member.remarks: The description may be presented to the user as the name of an available OPC server.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Location
member.summary: The server's location.
member.remarks: Corresponds to the host or machine name.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.ProgId
member.summary: Gets or sets a string value indicating the programmatic identifier (ProgID) of the OPC server.
member.remarks: ProgIDs present a human-readable version of the class identifier (CLSID) used to identify COM/ActiveX objects.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.ServerCategories
member.summary: Gets or sets information about which specifications the OPC server claims to support.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.ServerClass
member.summary: Returns a string usable for identification of the OPC server when passed to other methods. If the is not empty, it is used. Otherwise, if the is not empty, it is used. If both are empty, the string form of server's is returned.
member.remarks: For consistency, the corresponding property or parameter on other objects and methods is also called ServerClass.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Technology
member.summary: Determines the OPC technology used.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.UrlString
member.summary: A URL string of the server.

remarks.para: A generic string is used instead of , because in some cases, the value may not represent a real URI.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Vendor
member.summary: Gets or sets a vendor name.
member.remarks: Vendor name may be empty when unknown, e.g. if obtained through OPCEnum object which does not provide it. It is simply a means of identifying the vendor who supplied the particular OPC server.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.VersionIndependentProgId
member.summary: Gets or sets version-independent programmatic identifier of the OPC server application.

remarks.para: VersionIndependentProgId may be empty when unknown, e.g. if obtained through IOPCServerList interface of OPCEnum object which does not provide it, or when registry does not contain that information. In some cases (e.g. when IOPCServerList2 is used, and the VersionIndependentProgID is not available in the registry), the ProgID will be copied to this property.
The VersionIndependentProgID associates a ProgID with a CLSID.

The version-independent ProgID refers to the OPC server's class and does not change from version to version, instead remaining constant across all versions. It refers to the currently installed version of the OPC server's class. The version-independent ProgID corresponds to the name of the latest version of the OPC server application.

member.name: M:Opc.Da.PropertyID.#ctor(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.remarks: MP: During deserialization, SerializationInfo is passed to the class using the constructor provided for this purpose. Any visibility constraints placed on the constructor are ignored when the object is deserialized; so you can mark the class as public, protected, internal, or private. However, it is best practice to make the constructor protected unless the class is sealed, in which case the constructor should be marked private. The constructor should also perform thorough input validation. To avoid misuse by malicious code, the constructor should enforce the same security checks and permissions required to obtain an instance of the class using any other constructor.
